#

The estate of the person who died usually pays Inheritance Tax. You may need to pay Inheritance Tax if the estate can’t or doesn’t pay it.

#

#

If the will says the Inheritance Tax should be paid out of the assets you’ve inherited, the executor of the will or administrator of the estate will usually pay it.

#

You may have to pay Inheritance Tax on money and shares you inherit if the deceased person’s estate can’t or doesn’t pay.

#

You can apply to be a child’s special guardian when they cannot live with their birth parents and adoption is not right for them.

#

You’ll be responsible for looking after the child until they’re 18 (unless the court takes your responsibility away earlier).

#

You’ll make all day to day decisions about the child, for example schooling and medical treatment. You do not have to discuss these decisions with the birth parents.

#

You’ll need to get the consent of everyone who has parental responsibility for the child before you make some important decisions, for example:

#
  • taking the child abroad for more than 3 months
    • #

    If you cannot get consent, you can ask the court to decide. Use the form ‘Make an application in existing court proceedings related to children’ (form C2).

Eligibility

#

Housing Benefit can help you pay your rent if you’re unemployed, on a low income or claiming benefits. It’s being replaced by Universal Credit.

housing_benefit_can_help_pay_rent = True being_replaced_by_Universal_Credit = True #

You can only make a new claim for Housing Benefit if either of the following apply:

#
  • you have reached State Pension age
    • #
  • you’re in supported, sheltered or temporary housing
    • if reached_state_pension_age or in_supported_sheltered_or_temporary_housing: can_make_new_claim_for_Housing_Benefit = True #

    Council and social housing rent

    #

    How much you get depends on:

    #
  • your ‘eligible’ rent
    • #
  • if you have a spare room
    • #
  • your household income - including benefits, pensions and savings (over £6,000)
    • #
  • your circumstances, for example the age of people in the house or if someone has a disability
    • amount_of_Housing_Benefit_depends_on_eligible_rent = True amount_of_Housing_Benefit_depends_on_spare_room = True amount_of_Housing_Benefit_depends_on_household_income = True amount_of_Housing_Benefit_depends_on_circumstances = True #

    Spare bedrooms

    #

    Your Housing Benefit could be reduced if you live in council or social housing and have a spare bedroom. The reduction is:

    #
  • 14% of the ‘eligible rent’ for 1 spare bedroom
    • #
  • 25% of the ‘eligible rent’ for 2 or more spare bedrooms
    • if live_in_council_or_social_housing_and_have_spare_bedroom: if number_of_spare_bedrooms == 1: reduction_in_Housing_Benefit = 14 elif number_of_spare_bedrooms >= 2: reduction_in_Housing_Benefit = 25 #

    How much you can get

    #

    How much you get depends on:

    #
  • the lower figure of your ‘eligible’ rent or LHA rate
    • #
  • your household income including benefits, pensions and savings (over £6,000)
    • #
  • your circumstances (for example your age or whether you have a disability)
    • amount_of_Housing_Benefit_depends_on_eligible_rent_or_LHA_rate = True amount_of_Housing_Benefit_depends_on_household_income = True amount_of_Housing_Benefit_depends_on_circumstances = True #

    Contact your local council if you’re living in:

    #
  • a houseboat or a mooring
    • #
  • a caravan site
    • #
  • a room with any meals included in the rent (sometimes known as a boarding home)
    • #
  • a hostel
    • #
  • a Rent Act protected property

Community sentences can be given for crimes such as:

#

    • #

    • #

    You may get a community sentence if:

    #
  • the court thinks you’re more likely to stop committing crime than if you go to prison
    • #
  • it’s the first time you have committed a crime
    • #
  • you have a mental health condition that affects your behaviour

#

Overview

#

Special educational needs and disabilities (SEND) can affect a child or young person’s ability to learn. They can affect their:

if special_educational_needs_and_disabilities: #
  • behaviour or ability to socialise, for example they struggle to make friends
    • affects_behaviour_or_socialisation = True #
  • reading and writing, for example because they have dyslexia
    • affects_reading_and_writing = True #
  • ability to understand things
    • affects_ability_to_understand = True #
  • concentration levels, for example because they have ADHD
    • affects_concentration_levels = True #
  • physical ability
    • affects_physical_ability = True #

    Support your child can receive

    #

    Your child may be eligible for:

    #
  • SEN support - support given in school, like speech therapy
    • eligible_for_SEN_support = True #
  • an education, health and care (EHC) plan - a plan of care for children and young people aged up to 25 who have more complex needs
    • eligible_for_EHC_plan = True #

    If you or your child got support before September 2014 this will continue until your local council changes it to an EHC plan.

    if support_received_before_September_2014: support_continues_until_changed_to_EHC_plan = True #

    Special educational needs support

    #

    Your child will get SEN support at their school or college.

    child_gets_SEN_support_at_school_or_college = True #

    Your child may need an education, health and care (EHC) plan if they need more support than their school provides.

    if need_more_support_than_school_provides: child_may_need_EHC_plan = True #

    Extra help

    #

    An education, health and care (EHC) plan is for children and young people aged up to 25 who need more support than is available through special educational needs support.

    EHC_plan_for_children_and_young_people_who_need_more_support = True #

    EHC plans identify educational, health and social needs and set out the additional support to meet those needs.

    EHC_plans_identify_needs_and_set_out_additional_support = True #

    Requesting an EHC assessment

    #

    You can ask your local authority to carry out an assessment if you think your child needs an EHC plan.

    request_EHC_assessment = True #

    A young person can request an assessment themselves if they’re aged 16 to 25.

    young_person_aged_16_to_25_can_request_assessment = True #

    A request can also be made by anyone else who thinks an assessment may be necessary, including doctors, health visitors, teachers, parents and family friends.

    request_can_be_made_by_others = True #

    If they decide to carry out an assessment you may be asked for:

    #

  • doctors’ assessments of your child
    • doctors_assessments_required = True #
  • a letter from you about your child’s needs
    • letter_from_you_about_childs_needs_required = True #

    The local authority will tell you within 16 weeks whether an EHC plan is going to be made for your child.

    local_authority_will_notify_within_16_weeks = True

How it works

#

You and your partner may be able to get Shared Parental Leave (SPL) and Statutory Shared Parental Pay (ShPP) if you’re:

  • having a baby

    You need to share the pay and leave in the first year after your child is born or placed with your family.

    first_year_share_required = True #

    You can use SPL to take leave in blocks separated by periods of work, or take it all in one go. You can also choose to be off work together or to stagger the leave and pay.

    To get SPL and ShPP, you and your partner need to:

    #
  • meet the eligibility criteria - there’s different criteria for birth parents and criteria for adoptive parents or parents using a surrogate
    • #
  • give notice to your employers
    • if meet_eligibility_criteria and give_notice_to_employers: eligible_for_SPL = True elegible_for_ShPP = True #

    For SPL to start

    #

    The mother (or the person getting adoption leave) must either:

    #
  • return to work, which ends any maternity or adoption leave
    • #
  • give their employer ‘binding notice’ of the date when they plan to end their leave (you cannot normally change the date you give in binding notice)
    • if mother_or_person_getting_adoption_leave_return_to_work or binding_notice_given: SPL_can_start = True #

    You can start SPL while your partner is still on maternity or adoption leave as long as they’ve given binding notice to end it.

    start_SPL_while_partner_on_leave = True #

    You can give binding notice and say when you plan to take your SPL at the same time.

    If you’ve been impacted by coronavirus (COVID-19), you can get funding to continue to pay your employees instead of making them redundant. This is known as furloughing.

    if impacted_by_coronavirus: eligible_for_funding_to_pay_employees_instead_of_redundancy = True funding_known_as_furloughing = True #

    For a redundancy to be genuine, you must demonstrate that the employee’s job will no longer exist.

    redundancy_genuine_if_employee_job_no_longer_exists = True #

    Redundancies can be compulsory or non-compulsory. If you do have to make redundancies you can get help from Jobcentre Plus.

    redundancies_can_be_compulsory_or_non_compulsory = True if have_to_make_redundancies: can_get_help_from_Jobcentre_Plus = True #

    Statutory redundancy pay rates

    #

    These are based on an employee’s age and length of employment and are counted back from the date of dismissal.

  • 1.5 weeks’ pay for each full year of employment after their 41st birthday

  • a week’s pay for each full year of employment after their 22nd birthday

  • half a week’s pay for each full year of employment up to their 22nd birthday
    • statutory_redundancy_pay_for_each_full_year_up_to_22nd_birthday = True #

    Length of service is capped at 20 years.

    length_of_service_capped_at_20_years = True #

    Your employee’s weekly pay is the average they earned per week over the 12 weeks before the day they got their redundancy notice.

    employee_weekly_pay_based_on_average_earnings_over_12_weeks = True #

If you do not consult employees in a redundancy situation, any redundancies you make will almost certainly be unfair and you could be taken to an employment tribunal.

You must follow ‘collective consultation’ rules if you’re making 20 or more employees redundant within any 90-day period at a single establishment.

#

There are no set rules to follow if there are fewer than 20 redundancies planned, but it’s good practice to fully consult employees and their representatives. An employment tribunal could decide that you’ve dismissed your staff unfairly if you do not.

#

Consultation does not have to end in agreement, but it must be carried out with a view to reaching it, including ways of avoiding or reducing the redundancies.

I began trading on the first day that my company was established which makes it so I have to file a Company Tax Return covering a span of over 12 months. Is it ok for me to file only one Company Tax Return?
company_established_year = None # Year when the company was established
current_year = None # Current year
first_year_of_trading = None # Year when trading started
span_of_months = None # Number of months the Company Tax Return should cover
file_one_tax_return = None # This is the variable that answers the question
inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

When you set up your limited company, you automatically get different reporting dates for the first:

#
  • annual accounts you send to Companies House
    • #
  • Company Tax Return you send to HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC)
    • #

    You may also have to send (‘file’) 2 tax returns to cover your first year in business.

    if set_up_limited_company: #

    You started trading the day your company set up

    #

    File 2 Company Tax Returns if your company started trading on the same day it was set up - one for your company’s first 12 months and one for the rest of the time covered by your company’s first accounts.

    if started_trading_same_day_as_set_up: file_2_Company_Tax_Returns = True #

    Example

    # Action | Date # Company set up and started trading | 11 May 2013 # First accounting period for Corporation Tax ends | 10 May 2014 # Accounting reference date | 31 May 2014 # Second accounting period for Corporation Tax ends | 31 May 2014 #

    Prepare your first set of accounts for 11 May 2013 to 31 May 2014. Then file your:

    #
  • first tax return for 11 May 2013 to 10 May 2014
    • #
  • second tax return for 11 to 31 May 2014
    • #

    After you do this, your accounts and tax returns will normally cover your company’s financial year from 1 June to 31 May.

    if prepare_first_set_of_accounts: prepare_first_set_of_accounts = True #
  • first tax return for 11 May 2013 to 10 May 2014
    • file_first_tax_return = True #
  • second tax return for 11 to 31 May 2014
    • file_second_tax_return = True #

    Example

    # Action | Date # Company set up | 11 May 2013 # Started trading | 22 July 2013 # Register for Corporation Tax | 26 August 2013 # Accounting reference date | 31 May 2014 #

    Prepare accounts for 11 May 2013 to 31 May 2014. Then file one tax return for your trading period from 22 July 2013 to 31 May 2014.

    #

    After you do this, your dates for accounts and tax returns will normally match your company’s financial year from 1 June to 31 May every year.

    if prepare_accounts_for_trading_period: prepare_accounts_for_trading_period = True #
  • file one tax return for your trading period from 22 July 2013 to 31 May 2014
    • file_tax_return_for_trading_period = True #

    Check the ‘notice to deliver a Company Tax Return’ you get after your first year. If it covers your dormant and trading periods you must file 2 tax returns - one for your trading period and one for your dormant period.

    #

    Example:

    # Action | Date # Company set up | 11 May 2013 # Started trading | 22 July 2013 # Accounting reference date | 31 May 2014 #

    Prepare one set of accounts for 11 May 2013 to 31 May 2014. Then file your:

    #
  • first tax return for your dormant period from 11 May to 21 July 2013
    • #
  • second tax return for your trading period from 22 July 2013 to 31 May 2014
    • #

    After you do this, your dates for accounts and tax returns will normally match your company’s financial year from 1 June to 31 May every year.

    if check_notice_to_deliver_Company_Tax_Return: check_notice_to_deliver_Company_Tax_Return = True #
  • first tax return for your dormant period from 11 May to 21 July 2013
    • file_first_tax_return_for_dormant_period = True #
  • second tax return for your trading period from 22 July 2013 to 31 May 2014
    • file_second_tax_return_for_trading_period = True

inter_results.full_response:
#

You must file 2 tax returns - one for the period you were dormant and one for the period you were trading.

# Answer: yes

How it works

#

You and your partner may be able to get Shared Parental Leave (SPL) and Statutory Shared Parental Pay (ShPP) if you’re:

#
  • having a baby
    • #
  • using a surrogate to have a baby
    • #
  • adopting a child
    • if having_a_baby or using_surrogate or adopting_child: eligible_for_SPL_and_ShPP = True #

    You can share up to 50 weeks of leave and up to 37 weeks of pay between you.

    maximum_leave_weeks_is_50 = True maximum_pay_weeks_is_37 = True #

    You need to share the pay and leave in the first year after your child is born or placed with your family.

    first_year_share_required = True #

    You can use SPL to take leave in blocks separated by periods of work, or take it all in one go. You can also choose to be off work together or to stagger the leave and pay.

    SPL_blocks = True SPL_one_go = True SPL_together_or_stagger = True #

    To get SPL and ShPP, you and your partner need to:

    #
  • meet the eligibility criteria - there’s different criteria for birth parents and criteria for adoptive parents or parents using a surrogate
    • #
  • give notice to your employers
    • if meet_eligibility_criteria and give_notice_to_employers: eligible_for_SPL = True elegible_for_ShPP = True #

    For SPL to start

    #

    The mother (or the person getting adoption leave) must either:

    #
  • return to work, which ends any maternity or adoption leave
    • #
  • give their employer ‘binding notice’ of the date when they plan to end their leave (you cannot normally change the date you give in binding notice)
    • if mother_or_person_getting_adoption_leave_return_to_work or binding_notice_given: SPL_can_start = True #

    You can start SPL while your partner is still on maternity or adoption leave as long as they’ve given binding notice to end it.

    start_SPL_while_partner_on_leave = True #

    You can give binding notice and say when you plan to take your SPL at the same time.

    binding_notice_and_SPL_plans_together = True #

    A mother cannot return to work before the end of the compulsory 2 weeks of maternity leave following the birth (4 weeks if they work in a factory). If you’re adopting, the person claiming adoption pay must take at least 2 weeks of adoption leave.

    if (mother and not return_to_work_before_2_weeks) or (adopting and take_at_least_2_weeks_of_adoption_leave): compulsory_leave_requirements = True # Question: My partner has just had our second child and she wants to go back to work immediately, I will not be taking time off either.     A mother cannot return to work before the end of the compulsory 2 weeks of maternity leave following the birth (4 weeks if they work in a factory). If you’re adopting, the person claiming adoption pay must take at least 2 weeks of adoption leave.

You must tell DVLA if you’re taking your vehicle out of the UK, including to the Channel Islands (Jersey and Guernsey), Isle of Man or Ireland, for 12 months or more.

This is known as permanent export. You’ll need to:

#
  • Fill in the ‘permanent export’ section of your vehicle log book (V5C) and detach it from the log book.
    • #
  • Send the completed ‘permanent export’ section to DVLA, Swansea, SA99 1BD. Include a letter if you’ve moved abroad and want your vehicle tax refund (if you’re entitled to one) sent to your new address.
    • #
  • Keep the rest of your log book (V5C) - you need it to register your vehicle in the country you’re taking it to.
    • #
  • Update the address on your driving licence if you’re moving home.
    • #

    If you’re buying a vehicle to take abroad make sure the seller follows the correct process for vehicles that will be registered in another country. They must give you the full log book (V5C) - not just the new keeper slip.

#

You must tell DVLA if you’re taking your vehicle out of the UK, including to the Channel Islands (Jersey and Guernsey), Isle of Man or Ireland, for 12 months or more.

#

You’ll need to:

#
  • Fill in the ‘permanent export’ section of your vehicle log book (V5C) and detach it from the log book.
    • #
  • Send the completed ‘permanent export’ section to DVLA, Swansea, SA99 1BD. Include a letter if you’ve moved abroad and want your vehicle tax refund (if you’re entitled to one) sent to your new address.
    • #
  • Keep the rest of your log book (V5C) - you need it to register your vehicle in the country you’re taking it to.
    • #
  • Update the address on your driving licence if you’re moving home.
    • #

    You’ll need to transfer or retain your personalised registration before exporting your vehicle. Otherwise you’ll lose your right to the registration number.

#
  • outside the UK to Great Britain
    • #

    • #

    VAT is not charged on goods that are gifts worth £39 or less.

    #

    You pay VAT when you buy the goods or to the delivery company before you receive them. If you have to pay VAT to the delivery company, it’s charged on the total package value, including:

    #
  • the value of the goods
    • #
  • postage, packaging and insurance
    • #
  • any duty you owe
    • #

    VAT is charged at the VAT rate that applies to your goods.

    #

    If you bought the goods yourself and they are not excise goods, the seller will have included VAT in the total you paid.

    #

    You will need to pay VAT to the delivery company if the goods are:

    #
  • gifts sent to you by someone else and worth more than £39
    • #
  • excise goods
    • # Answer: yes

  • using a surrogate to have a baby
    • #

    You can share up to 50 weeks of leave and up to 37 weeks of pay between you.

    maximum_leave_weeks_is_50 = True maximum_pay_weeks_is_37 = True #

    You need to share the pay and leave in the first year after your child is born or placed with your family.

    first_year_share_required = True #

    You can use SPL to take leave in blocks separated by periods of work, or take it all in one go. You can also choose to be off work together or to stagger the leave and pay.

    SPL_blocks = True SPL_one_go = True SPL_together_or_stagger = True #

    To get SPL and ShPP, you and your partner need to:

  • give notice to your employers

    For SPL to start

  • return to work, which ends any maternity or adoption leave

  • give their employer ‘binding notice’ of the date when they plan to end their leave (you cannot normally change the date you give in binding notice)

    binding_notice_and_SPL_plans_together = True #
